entries.meaning: A blank booklet of lined paper used in the administration of examinations, so named because of its pale blue front and back covers.
examples: Bluebooks are designed to prevent cheating but sometimes they provide cover for cheaters when the student brings an extra blue book with notes, equations, dates, etc. (Wein 1).

verbs.description: bluebook (third-person singular simple present bluebooks, present participle bluebooking, simple past and past participle bluebooked)

entries.meaning: (law) To format a document, particularly a legal document including citations, according to the rules of the Bluebook, a US style guide.
examples: After all, the nonmember author who has never participated in the endless chores of bluebooking and typing is more successful than most law review members in writing a piece of publishable quality.

entries.meaning: (role-playing games) To have players describe, in writing and in-between regular role-playing sessions, character activities that don't involve the entire group.
